Graphical abstract This review summarizes the safety issues plaguing sodium ion batteries and the research progress of safety improvement strategies, providing guidance and assistance for designing highly safe sodium ion batteries. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with advantages of abundant resource and low cost have emerged as promising candidates for the next-generation energy storage systems. However, safety issues existing in electrolytes, anodes, and cathodes bring about frequent accidents regarding battery fires and explosions and impede the development of high-performance SIBs. Therefore, safety analysis and high-safety battery design have become prerequisites for the development of advanced energy storage systems. The reported reviews that only focus on a specific issue are difficult to provide overall guidance for building high-safety SIBs. To overcome the limitation, this review summarizes the recent research progress from the perspective of key components of SIBs for the first time and evaluates the characteristics of various improvement strategies. By orderly analyzing the root causes of safety problems associated with different components in SIBs (including electrolytes, anodes, and cathodes), corresponding improvement strategies for each component were discussed systematically. In addition, some noteworthy points and perspectives including the chain reaction between security issues and the selection of improvement strategies tailored to different needs have also been proposed. In brief, this review is designed to deepen our understanding of the SIBs safety issues and provide guidance and assistance for designing high-safety SIBs. Keywords Sodium ion batteries Safety Organic electrolytes modification Solid-state electrolyte Anode bulk modification Cathode bulk design 1 Introduction In order to reduce pollution during the use of fossil fuels and meet the huge energy demand of future society, the development of sustainable renewable energy and efficient energy storage systems has become a research hotspot worldwide [1–3]. Among energy storage systems, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) exhibit excellent electrochemical performance, which have been widely employed in portable electronic devices and electric vehicles [4–6]. However, the regions of consumption and supply of lithium resources are totally different, resulting in uncontrollable increase of the LIBs cost and serious risk for supply chain. In addition, frequent safety accidents such as fires and explosions also raise concerns about the safety of LIBs [7–10]. Over the years, the practical demand for developing new energy storage systems with low cost and high safety has driven the development of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Compared to LIBs, SIBs exhibit many advantages such as abundant raw material resources, low cost, and excellent low-temperature performance [11–13]. Notably, many research have proven that SIBs have extremely high potential for building high-safety energy storage systems. Passerini et al. found that pure sodium salts, as important raw materials for SIBs, exhibit better thermal stability compared to similar lithium salts, which endows SIBs with higher safety [14]. Ma’s group investigated the thermal runaway behavior of SIBs through accelerating rate calorimetry (ARC) and found that SIBs using Na x Ni1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 cathode can reach a top temperature of 312.24 °C during thermal runaway, which is lower than that of LIBs [15]. In addition, SIBs have a lower risk of short circuit, because the separator of SIBs is less susceptible to penetration by sodium dendrites with lower mechanical strength compared to lithium dendrites [16]. However, this does not imply that the safety concerns of SIBs can be neglected. Similar to LIBs, the most widely used electrolyte in SIBs is organic electrolyte. The flammability, high electrochemical reactivity, and corrosiveness of organic liquid electrolytes bring about serious safety hazards to SIBs [17,18]. Additionally, the radius of Na ions is larger than that of Li ions, leading to greater volume changes and structural collapse in cathode during Na insertion/extraction [19]. Up to now, numerous strategies from the aspects of electrolytes, anodes, and cathodes have been developed to build high-safety SIBs. The strategies for designing high-safety electrolytes include organic liquid electrolyte modification, solid state electrolytes (SSEs), and aqueous electrolyte. Organic electrolytes modification can improve the electrolyte intrinsic stability and alleviate the safety issues such as sodium dendrites, solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) decomposition, and side reactions [18]. By replacing organic electrolytes with SSEs and aqueous electrolytes with extremely low flammability, the risk of combustion and explosion of SIBs will be greatly reduced [20–22]. In addition, the strategies starting from anode and cathode, including artificial SEI, anode bulk modification, and cathode bulk design, can also enhance the safety of SIBs. By constructing an artificial protective layer on the pristine anode surface, artificial SEI can effectively improve anode stability and overall safety of SIBs [23]. Anode bulk modification with low cost can effectively suppress sodium dendrites, SEI decomposition, and side reactions by adjusting the structure and chemical environment of the anode surface [24,25]. Through enhancing the intrinsic stability of the cathode, cathode bulk design can suppress cathode thermal decomposition and mechanical structure damage, constructing high-safety SIBs with excellent electrochemical performance [26]. However, most of the current review literature focuses on a specific issue such as thermal runaway and short circuit caused by dendrites and corresponded improvement strategies, resulting in difficulty to provide guidance for enhancing the overall SIBs safety [16,27,28]. To fill the gap in all-round security improvement, this review comprehensively reviews advanced modification strategies from three perspectives: electrolyte, anode, and cathode, as shown in Fig. 1 . Since SIBs failure is caused by chain reactions, an in-depth profiling of the causes of battery safety issues associated with each component and corresponding impacts are presented at first. Subsequently, various improvement strategies targeting specific security issues according to different components are analyzed and compared, including clarifying promoting mechanisms and evaluating features and performance. Notably, a summary and guidance for designing high-safety SIBs are proposed in the end, aiming to deepen researchers' understanding of the SIBs safety issues and stimulate the development of high-safety SIBs. 2 The safety issues in sodium-ion batteries SIBs are mainly composed of three parts: electrolyte, anode, and cathode. In general, the different intrinsic characteristics and specific usage environment of these key components bring different safety issues that can hinder the further application of SIBs. For example, the intrinsic instability of electrolytes, including flammability, high electrochemical reactivity, and corrosiveness, poses significant safety concerns for electrolytes. The safety of the anode is seriously threatened by sodium dendrites, SEI decomposition, and side reactions. Cathodes need to prevent failure caused by thermal decomposition and mechanical structural damage. In addition, the above notorious issues do not exist independently but interact with each other. For example, a typical thermal runaway process is affected by a series of continuous and complex thermal reactions (Fig. 2 ) associated with different components in SIBs (including electrolyte, anode, and cathode), consisting of three stages [27–29]. (1) Pre-stage. Unfavorable external conditions and internal battery problems can cause overheating (Fig. 3 a and b). Specifically, external factors mainly include high ambient temperature and overcharging. The internal factors involving key materials are Na dendrites, structure collapse of the cathode materials, and current collector corrosion. In addition, the unavoidable interface reaction between electrolyte and anode/anode will also cause overheating of SIBs. (2) Heat accumulation stage. A series of thermal reactions, associated with electrolyte, anode, and cathode, rapidly increase battery temperature. (a) SEI decomposition. As the temperature increases, the SEI begins to decompose (Fig. 2a). The inorganic components in the SEI, such as ROCO2Na (R stands for alkyl groups), are sensitive to temperature, and their decomposition will release gases and further increase the temperature of SIBs [30]. (b) Anode-electrolyte reactions. Once SEI decomposes, the anode surface will directly contact with the electrolyte and more violent anode-electrolyte reactions occur (Fig. 2b). For example, the reaction between the Na anode and propylene carbonate (PC, C4H6O3) will release a large amount of heat and flammable gases. (c) Cathode thermal decomposition. After reaching a certain temperature, the cathode (Na x MO2) starts to decompose and releases a large amount of heat with the liberation of oxygen (Fig. 2c). The oxygen will not only further increase the air pressure inside the battery, but also react with the anode and electrolyte to accelerate the temperature rise [31]. (3) Thermal abuse stage. Once the heat and pressure inside the battery reach the burning point of the organic solvent in the electrolyte, the battery will be completely out of control until it burns or even explodes (Fig. 2d). Based on the above analysis, strengthening the understanding of battery safety issues, especially analyzing the root causes of safety issues from the perspective of key battery materials, is an important way to reduce safety risks and promote the practical application of SIBs. In the following chapters, we comprehensively analyze and summarize the factors affecting battery safety from three aspects: electrolyte, anode, and cathode. 2.1 Electrolyte Electrolyte as an important component of batteries plays a crucial role in transporting ions between the cathode and anode. The intrinsic instability, including flammability, high electrochemical reactivity, and high corrosiveness, of the electrolyte is highly related to battery safety issues and have attracted widespread attention [32]. 2.1.1 Flammability Organic electrolytes are widely used in SIBs due to their excellent electrochemical stability and ion transport ability. However, their volatile and flammable properties bring about serious safety hazards to SIBs [17]. The electrolytes of SIBs are mainly composed of solvents and sodium salts. The flammability of SIBs electrolytes mostly comes from organic solvents, which have very low flash points. For example, the mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has an extremely low flash point of 25 ± 1 °C at a pressure of 1.013 bar [9]. This means that organic electrolytes can not only be easily ignited by external heat sources (Fig. 3c) [33]. The heat and oxygen released by the cathode during thermal runaway inside the battery can also provide the necessary conditions for the combustion of electrolytes, thereby causing fire or explosion hazards. It is worth noting that organic solvents will decompose during the heating process, which generates gas and increases the atmospheric pressure inside the battery, resulting in the heat release to make the heating process more rapid [34]. In addition, sodium salts can seriously affect the safety of electrolytes. Normally, the thermal stability of sodium salts in electrolytes are better than lithium salts which are easily decomposed at high temperatures, giving SIBs a certain safety advantage over LIBs [14]. Among common sodium salts, NaClO4 has the best thermal stability, bringing it broader application prospects. The flammability of electrolytes is the most serious safety hazard in the application of SIBs. Although various nonflammable electrolytes have been successfully developed, there is still no nonflammable electrolyte that can completely replace traditional organic electrolytes due to various reasons such as electrochemical performance and cost [18]. 2.1.2 High electrochemical reactivity The electrochemical reactivity of the SIBs electrolyte determines the size of the electrochemically stable window (ESW), which not only affects the safety of SIBs, but also decides the application range of the battery. Organic electrolytes generally have high electrochemical reactivity. Under high voltage, they decompose to produce harmful byproducts such as hydrofluoric acid (HF), enhancing the inherent corrosiveness of the electrolyte and severely accelerating the decomposition of SEI and cathode [35,36]. In addition, the high-voltage decomposition of the electrolyte will also produce gases such as ethylene gas (C2H4) and carbon monoxide (CO), which will increase the internal pressure of the battery and increase the risk of electrolyte combustion. Therefore, inhibiting the electrochemical reaction activity of the electrolyte and broadening the ESW are crucial for improving the safety of SIBs [37]. In electrolytes, due to the similar electrochemical stability of all sodium salts, solvents are the main factor affecting the electrochemical reactivity [34]. As shown in Fig. 3(d and e), when NaClO4 is also chosen as the sodium salt, the electrochemical reactivity of diethyl carbonate (DEC) is much lower than that of dimethyl ether (DME) and DMC. However, when mixed with EC as a binary solvent, due to the synergistic effect of solvent mixing, the electrochemical reactivity of EC-DEC is significantly increased. At present, research on suppressing the high electrochemical reactivity of SIBs electrolytes mainly focuses on electrolyte modification. SSEs are regarded as future solutions to this problem due to their excellent electrochemical stability. 2.1.3 Corrosiveness Unlike lithium, sodium is difficult to form an alloy with aluminum current collectors. Therefore, aluminum foil can be used as the current collectors for SIBs anodes instead of copper foil, which brings considerable cost advantages to SIBs. But because of this, the safety hazards caused by the corrosion of aluminum foil by electrolytes are often overlooked [38]. The corrosiveness of electrolytes to aluminum is closely related to sodium salts. For example, the corrosiveness of NaFSI-based electrolytes is much more severe than that of NaPF6-based and NaClO4-based electrolytes [14]. In addition, temperature also has a significant impact on the corrosiveness of the electrolyte to aluminum. At 20 °C, when Al is placed in the NaFSI-PC electrolyte environment, most surfaces are not affected by corrosion. When the working temperature was increased to 55 °C (Fig. 3f), severe pitting corrosion occurred on the entire electrode surface [39]. If the corrosion of electrolyte on aluminum is not controlled and expanded, it will eventually cause perforation of the aluminum foil, posing the risk of short circuit to the battery. Currently, inhibiting the corrosion of electrolyte on aluminum foil mainly relies on electrolyte modification, and more pioneering work is still needed. 2.2 Anode As an important component of SIBs, anodes have been developed with significant progress in the research of SIBs, including the widely used Na metal, C-based materials, Sn, Ge, and the other alloy anodes [40–43]. However, due to the instability of SEI and the risk of dendrite growth under low voltage, SIB anode faces serious safety issues [44,45]. 2.2.1 SEI decomposition and side reactions During the initial few cycles of SIBs, SEI is formed on the surface of the anode material, which prevents continuous side reactions between the anode and the electrolyte. But the SEI on the anode surface usually decomposes and ruptures at a temperature of about 100 °C, and then further chemical reactions occur between the anode and the electrolyte, releasing a large amount of heat. The temperature of SEI decomposition is much lower than the temperature at which the cathode material begins to thermally decompose. Therefore, the SEI decomposition and side reactions on the anode often serve as the starting point for thermal runaway in SIBs safety accidents [46,47]. The schematic diagram of SEI decomposition and side reactions on the Sn anode surface is shown in Fig. 4 (a). Firstly, SEI is generated on the Sn anode surface, but when the temperature rises to 50–200 °C, SEI begins to decompose, resulting in the first mild exothermic reaction caused by the thermal decomposition reaction of the SEI. Then, as the SEI ruptures, a side reaction occurs between the anode and electrolyte, resulting in a more intense second exothermic reaction [48]. During this process, SEI will be continuously regenerated, but because the decomposition process of SEI is usually faster than the formation of new SEI at high temperatures, such side reactions will continue to occur between the anode and electrolyte, and the accumulated heat will eventually cause cathode thermal runaway and electrolyte combustion [49]. It is worth noting that due to the higher solubility of hydroxide and carbonate formed during the generation of SEI compared to corresponding Li and K compounds in organic solvents, the SEI of SIBs is more unstable than that of lithium-ion and potassium ion batteries. This means that SEI decomposition and side reactions bring more serious safety issues to SIBs than to LIBs and PIBs [50]. The stability of SEI and the intensity of heat release from side reactions are closely related to anode materials [44,48]. Due to the different chemical and electrochemical properties of Na metal, C-based materials, Sn, and other alloy materials, there are significant differences in the generated SEI on the surface of electrode. For example, due to extremely high reactivity, the Na metal anode will undergo a thermal reaction with the electrolyte even at lower temperatures, resulting in metastable SEI on the surface of Na metal anode. As the temperature increases, the metastable SEI decomposes, and the Na metal anode with high reactivity undergoes a violent exothermic reaction in direct contact with the electrolyte. In addition, the low melting point of Na metal (approximately 98 °C) further exacerbates the risk of thermal runaway in SIBs. Thorough mixing of molten Na and electrolyte increases the reactivity of anodeelectrolyte reactions and releases a large amount of heat. More seriously, when the separator melts, molten Na with fluidity is easily in contact with the cathode, which will cause a short circuit and instantaneous intense release of heat, posing a risk of combustion and explosion to SIBs [51]. In addition, electrolyte, as one of the sources of SEI components, also influences the thermal stability of SEI [14]. The thermal stability of SEI formed on hard carbon in various electrolytes is illustrated in Fig. 4(b), where sodium salts and solvents both affect the temperature and total heat of the first exothermic reaction. In the same solvent, NaPF6-EC: PC has a higher initial exothermic temperature than NaClO4-EC: PC. When NaClO4 is used as a sodium salt, the total heat release of NaClO4-EC: PC is much smaller than that of NaClO4-EC: DEC [34]. Inhibiting SEI decomposition and side reactions requires improving the thermal stability of the SEI film, as well as reducing the reaction activity and heat released between the electrolyte and anode. This means that eliminating the safety hazards faced by the anode requires simultaneous modification of the electrolyte and anode material. 2.2.2 Sodium dendrite For sodium metal anodes, in addition to SEI decomposition and side reactions, the growth of Na dendrites can also affect the safety performance of SIBs. The growing dendrite will continuously damage the SEI, even piercing the separator and causing a short circuit [16,51,52]. The growth process of Na dendrites is shown in Fig. 4(c). The non-uniform surface of Na metal can lead to uneven Na deposition during the initial electroplating process, resulting in more concentrated Na flux at the protrusions and ultimately producing coarse dendrites [53]. Although both belong to alkali metals and have similarities, Na metals inherently exhibit more active chemical properties and different physical and mechanical properties compared to Li. In general, Na dendrites have poorer chemical stability and are more sensitive to electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 4(d and e), after galvanostatic charging, both Li dendrites and Na dendrites are generated on the electrode surface. However, under the quasi-zero electrochemical field (an electrochemical system where external electrochemical processes are halted), Li dendrites do not decrease during the settling process, while Na dendrites gradually dissolve and decrease. In addition, the mechanical stability of Na dendrites is also worse, and they are easily peeled off from the electrode surface under external influence [54]. Due to the poorer chemical and mechanical stability of Na dendrites compared to Li dendrites, the SEI on the surface of Na metal anodes is more unstable, making it easier for the anode to react with the electrolyte. However, this also means that Na dendrites are less likely to penetrate the separator than Li dendrites. In order to reduce the danger of lithium dendrites, it is necessary to simultaneously enhance the stability of SEI and enhance the mechanical strength of the diaphragm, while for Na dendrites, more emphasis should be placed on the former. 2.3 Cathode For SIBs, the cathode material provides active sodium ions and high potential redox electron pairs, which are key to determining the electrochemical performance of the battery. At present, various cathode material systems such as layered oxides, polyanionic compounds, and Prussian Blue analogs have been used in SIBs [55,56]. However, the cathode of SIBs also faces serious safety issues such as thermal runaway and mechanical structural damage [19,26,57–59]. 2.3.1 Thermal decomposition The SEI decomposition and side reactions of anode occur at lower temperatures, while the thermal decomposition of cathode often occurs at higher temperatures. But once the continuously rising temperature causes cathode material to decompose, it will release a large amount of heat and oxygen, causing the temperature and pressure inside the battery to increase exponentially, greatly increasing the risk of battery combustion and explosion [15,27,29]. Among the cathode systems of SIBs, the thermal safety issue of layered oxides is the most severe. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), as the temperature increases, the Na x CoO2 cathode will undergo thermal decomposition from the edge of the particles and gradually ascend into the interior of the particles. At high temperatures, Na x CoO2 will gradually decompose into Co3O4, CoO, and even Co metal, releasing a large amount of heat accompanied by the release of lattice oxygen in Na x CoO2 [60]. O2 not only accelerates the decomposition of electrolyte, but also increases the internal pressure of the battery, increasing the risk of electrolyte combustion. In addition to layered oxides, other SIBs cathodes such as polyanionic compounds also undergo thermal decomposition [61]. The thermal stability of cathodes is related to their charge/discharge state [62]. The O K-edge and Co L 2,3 edge electron energy loss (EEL) spectra of Na x CoO2 cathode materials under different voltages during heating process are shown in Fig. 5(b). At 400 °C, the changes in O K-edge and Co L 2,3 edge of Na x CoO2 (4.3 V) are more pronounced than those of lower voltage Na x CoO2. The O K-edge of Na x CoO2 (4.3 V) almost disappears, indicating that most oxygen is released from the Na x CoO2 material. The abnormal decrease of L 3/L 2 ratio of Co L-edge at 400 °C is due to the final reduction of Co ions to metallic Co. This proves that at the same temperature, the higher the cutoff voltage of Na x CoO2, the more severe the thermal decomposition will be. When the cut-off voltage is increased from 3.5 to 4.3 V, the thermal stability of Na x CoO2 cathode will significantly decrease, making it more prone to oxygen precipitation and transition metal reduction [60]. In addition, the thermal stability of cathode materials in the discharge state (2 V) is worse than that in the charged state (4 V). Not only does the initial temperature of thermal decomposition decrease, but the total heat energy released in the discharge state (594 J g−1) is also higher than that in the charged state (312 J g−1) [63]. Although the thermal decomposition of the cathode is mainly affected by its own characteristics and state, the influence of the cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) film cannot be ignored. The decomposition of CEI can lead to side reactions between the cathode and electrolyte, inducing excessive reduction and surface reconstruction, making the thermal decomposition of the cathode more severe [64]. The thermal safety issue of the cathode is significantly different from that of the anode. The heat released by anode thermal runaway is dominated by SEI and the side reaction between anode and electrolyte, while the heat released by cathode thermal runaway comes more from its decomposition. This means that to solve the thermal safety problem of the cathode, more attention needs to be paid to improving the thermal stability of the cathode itself. 2.3.2 Structural damage In addition to thermal decomposition, mechanical structural damage can also pose serious safety issues to the cathode. When structural cracks or even active material detachment occur in the cathode due to external mechanical action or internal stress accumulation, it can cause a short circuit in the battery and even lead to uncontrolled explosion [26,57–59]. The main cause of mechanical structural damage in cathode comes from internal stress. The cathode undergoes a phase transition during sodium insertion/extraction, which not only causes changes from one phase to another, as shown in Fig. 5(c), but also results in volume changes and structural cracks [65]. The radius of sodium ions is larger than that of lithium ions, which brings about greater volume changes in SIBs during charge and discharge cycles, and poses a more serious risk of mechanical damage [66]. As a typical type of SIBs cathode materials, layered oxides can be classified into P2 or O3 types according to their structures. During charge and discharge cycles, P2 and O3 phases often undergoes a series of phase transitions, resulting in irreversible volume changes. P2-type layered oxides undergo a P2-O2 phase transition under high pressure. Due to the difference in lattice parameters between P2 and O2 structures, a huge strain is established at the P2/O2 phase boundary, leading to the formation of cracks. At the crack tip, transition metals are prone to dissolution and migration, as shown in Fig. 5(d), which gradually causes the crack to propagate from the phase boundary to the grain blocks during the cyclic process. Subsequent surface corrosion will cause cracks to expand until the cathode material breaks and falls off [67]. The structural stability of O3 phase is worse than that of P2 phase, and the extraction of sodium ions will lead to extremely complex phase transitions (O3 → O′3 → P3 → P′3 → P3″). These complex phase transitions usually lead to structural degradation and high stress, making O3 phase more prone to mechanical structural damage [68]. In addition, external mechanical forces can also damage the mechanical structure of the cathode of SIBs. Cathode materials with weaker mechanical strength may not only experience cracks and particle damage when subjected to external mechanical forces, such as electrode processing or accidental collisions with batteries, but their internal crystal structure may also undergo changes or even be destroyed [69]. Improving the intrinsic structural stability of cathode materials is crucial for preventing mechanical structural damage to the cathode of SIBs. In addition, external strategies such as improving the stability and adhesive force of binder and inhibiting the dissolution of transition metals in the electrolyte can also alleviate mechanical structural damage to the cathode [70]. Various safety issues existing in electrolytes, anodes, and cathodes impede the construction of high-safety SIBs, and these issues are generated from different root causes. Intrinsic instability of the electrolytes, including high flammability, high electrochemical reactivity, and corrosiveness, poses electrolytes significant security risks. Anodes face challenges from sodium dendrites, SEI decomposition, and side reaction, which originate from the complex reactions occurring between the anode and the electrolyte. Unstable crystal structure and irreversible phase transition can cause thermal decomposition and mechanical structural damage to the cathode, ultimately resulting in failure. In addition, these security issues do not exist in isolation, but will affect each other and even have a chain reaction. This means that to improve the safety of SIBs, we need to propose targeted solutions from the root, while comprehensively considering the mutual influence of multiple security issues. This will be fully reflected in the chapter on security issue resolution strategies below. 3 Strategies for high-safety sodium-ion batteries 3.1 Electrolyte As an important component of SIBs, electrolytes play a crucial role in determining the safety of SIBs. The safety strategy based on electrolyte modification can simultaneously solve the inherent safety issues of electrolytes and improve the safety of the anode and cathode. At present, there are several strategies for designing high-safety electrolytes, based on organic liquid electrolytes modification, SSEs, and aqueous electrolytes [18,21,22]. 3.1.1 Organic electrolytes modification Organic liquid electrolytes with excellent electrochemical performance are applied as the most common electrolytes in SIBs. However, the intrinsic instability of the electrolytes including high flammability, high electrochemical reactivity, and corrosiveness triggers serious safety issues, impeding the development of high-safety SIBs. Due to the easily regulated components, typical modification strategies such as electrolyte additives, solvent regulation, and highly concentrated electrolytes have been reported to improve the electrolyte stability and alleviate the safety issues such as sodium dendrites, SEI decomposition, side reactions, cathode thermal decomposition, and mechanical structure damage [71,72]. 3.1.1.1 Low flammability The flammability of electrolytes poses SIBs the most serious safety issues. Traditional carbonate-based electrolytes generally have extremely high flammability and volatility, resulting in extremely low flash points and greatly increasing the risk of combustion of SIBs [9,14]. By introducing flame retardant components such as phosphorus-based and fluorine-based solvent, the combustion risk of electrolyte can be effectively reduced. Among all phosphates, trimethyl phosphate (TMP) is a suitable choice for safe electrolytes due to its excellent electrochemical performance and chemical stability [73,74]. Fig. 6 (a) compares the flammability of TMP electrolyte and carbonate electrolyte. Carbonate electrolyte can be easily ignited, while all TMP electrolytes have excellent flame retardancy [75]. Fluorine-based solvents can also effectively reduce the flammability of organic solvents. Fluorine substitution can reduce the intramolecular hydrogen content and capture oxygen and hydrogen radicals during ignition, thereby reducing flammability [76,77]. Perfluoro-2-methyl-3-pentanone (PFMP) is often used as a fireproof agent, which can reduce the flammability of electrolyte and provide in-situ heat dissipation function. During the abnormal heat release process of the battery, PFMP can absorb heat through evaporation to prevent thermal runaway of the battery [77]. In addition, other flame-retardant additives and nonflammable solvents, such as sulfolane, can also be used to effectively reduce the flammability of electrolytes. Highly concentrated electrolyte can reduce the risk of electrolyte combustion by reducing the volatility of the electrolyte. By increasing the salt concentration, the interaction between cations and anions/solvents is enhanced, and the molecular content of free solvents is reduced or even eliminated, resulting in the formation of a special three-dimensional solvation structure. The strong interaction between cations and solvent molecules can reduce solvent volatility and flash point, greatly improving the safety of electrolytes. However, the high salt concentration results in increased viscosity and cost of the electrolyte [78]. In order to simultaneously achieve flame retardant function and reduce viscosity, a local highly concentrated electrolyte with low viscosity, high wettability, and low cost is proposed, which can be designed by adding a non-solvent diluent to the high concentration electrolyte [79,80]. 3.1.1.2 Low electrochemical reactivity The high electrochemical reactivity of organic liquid electrolytes makes them prone to oxidation and decomposition under high voltage, which not only affects the safety of SIBs, but also limits the use of high-voltage cathodes. The use of solvents with high oxidation stability benefits to reduce high electrochemical reactivity and broaden the electrochemical reaction window [71]. Due to the high chemical and electrochemical stability, phosphate-based electrolyte exhibits low flammability and high oxidation potentials, making them less prone to exothermic high-voltage decomposition and improving the thermal safety of SIBs. For example, TMP-based electrolytes can maintain electrochemical stability at 4.5 V without significant thermal reactions occurring [79,80]. In addition, when NaTFSI is used as a sodium salt, the extensive coordination between TMP/TFSI− and Na+ can stabilize electron lone-pairs and improve the oxidation stability of solvents and anions, resulting in an oxidation potential of over 5 V [75]. Highly concentrated electrolyte can effectively improve oxidation stability by increasing the coordination number between solvents and cations [81]. In addition, after diluting the highly concentrated electrolyte with a low-polarity solvent, a local highly concentrated electrolyte can be obtained, which retains the unique local coordination structure and can also obtain extremely high oxidation potential [78]. Through solvation structure design, carbonate-based electrolytes can also achieve high oxidation stability. Fig. 6(b) shows the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test curves of carbonate-based electrolyte and solvated structure modified carbonate-based electrolyte. 1 M NaPF6 in EC/DEC electrolyte begins to oxidize at 3.77 V, while the oxidation potential increases to 4.75 V when NaClO4 and trimethoxy (pentafluorophenyl) silane (TPFS) are added as dual additives (DA). During the charging process, ClO4 − can quickly transfer to the cathode surface, coordinate strongly with Na, form stable polymer like chains with the solvent, and inhibit solvent decomposition. TPFS can preferentially coordinate with PF6 − to weaken the interactions with PF6 − solvent, greatly improving the oxidation stability of the electrolyte. The solvation structure effectively reduces the electrochemical reactivity and enhances oxidation stability of carbonate-based electrolytes, which greatly improves the safety of SIBs. At the same time, since there is no need to significantly change the composition of the carbonate-based electrolyte, it has great electrochemical performance and cost advantages [82]. 3.1.1.3 Inhibiting SEI decomposition and side reactions Traditional carbonate-based electrolytes generate organic-rich SEI on the anode surface. As the battery temperature increases, the organic components in SEI gradually decompose, leading to the destruction of the entire SEI. Subsequently, the electrode and electrolyte come into contact without SEI barrier, resulting in a side reaction of heating, causing the battery temperature to rapidly rise. Organic electrolyte modification can greatly improve the thermal safety of SIBs by increasing the content of thermally stable inorganic substances in SEI, inhibiting the decomposition of SEI and preventing the occurrence of hydrogen reactions [34,83]. Introducing additives can effectively improve the thermal stability of SEI [84–86]. For example, when fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) with higher reactivity than carbonate-based solvents is used as an additive, FEC will first decompose on the surface of anode, generating a dense NaF-rich SEI. Compared to organic-rich SEI, the NaF-rich SEI derived from FEC-containing electrolyte not only has a higher decomposition temperature, but also releases less total heat during the decomposition process (Fig. 6c), which can prevent thermal degradation of anode [48]. Furthermore, when tris(trimethylsilyl)phosphate (TMSP) and FEC are added to the electrolyte as binary additive combination, TMSP can react with the HF generated by FEC decomposition to form SiF, generating a more dense and thermally stable SiF-rich SEI [84]. Adjusting the composition of SEI by changing solvents can also effectively suppress SEI dissolution and side reactions. Compared to carbonate-based electrolytes, ether-based electrolytes tend to generate SEI with stronger thermal stability on the anode surface. The decomposition temperature of SEI generated on the surface of Na2Ti3O7/C in ether-based electrolytes (1 M NaBF4 in tetraglyme) is much higher than that generated in carbonate-based electrolytes (1 M NaClO4 in EC/PC) (Fig. 6d) [87]. The thermal stability of SEI derived from ether-based electrolytes comes from its rich inorganic components. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of SEI formed in 1 M NaPF6 in diglyme is shown in Fig. 6(e). The SEI is mainly composed of inorganic Na2O and NaF, with only a small amount of organic matter (RCH2ONa). This uniform inorganic SEI has high thermal stability and extremely low permeability, which is not easily soluble at high temperatures. At the same time, it can effectively suppress the side reactions between the electrolyte and the anode, greatly improving the safety of SIBs [88]. 3.1.1.4 Suppress sodium dendrite Uneven deposition of sodium ions on the anode surface can lead to the formation and growth of dendrites, posing serious safety risks to SIBs. Since dendrite growth occurs at the interface between the anode and electrolyte, involving various chemical and electrochemical reactions, organic electrolytes modification can effectively suppress sodium dendrite [24]. Electrolyte additives have been widely used to prevent the formation of dendrites on the anode of SIBs. For example, when FEC is added to 1 M NaClO4 in EC/PC electrolyte, FEC will first decompose during charge discharge cycles, producing SEI containing NaF. This improved SEI provides uniform sodium conductivity and can effectively inhibit the formation and growth of dendrites. Dual functional electrolyte additives, such as bis (trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide (KTFSI), can effectively inhibit the growth of sodium dendrites due to the functionalization effect of both anions and cations [89]. The TFSI− anions decompose into oxynitrides, forming an ideal SEI, while the K cation preferentially adsorbs on the Na protrusion, producing an electrostatic shielding effect that can prevent the concentration of sodium flux at the protrusion [90]. The unique solvation structure of highly concentrated electrolyte and localized highly concentrated electrolyte can also effectively suppress dendrites. The solvation structure dominated by solvents in low concentrated electrolyte often leads to solvent preferential decomposition, forming embedded SEI rich in organic components, which is conducive to dendritic nucleation and growth. In highly concentrated electrolyte, the solvation structure dominated by concentrated salts and anions is conducive to the decomposition of anions, resulting in SEI rich in inorganic components, which can effectively inhibit dendrites [81,91,92]. It is worth noting that when highly concentrated electrolyte and additives are applied simultaneously to the electrolyte, a synergistic effect can be generated, which can more effectively inhibit sodium dendrite. The schematic diagrams of sodium dendrite growth in traditional carbonate-based electrolyte, highly concentrated electrolyte, and highly concentrated electrolyte + 1% SbF3 additive are shown in Fig. 6(f). During electrochemical cycling, SbF3 additive can form a unique Na-Sb alloy layer, and the regulated solvation structure in highly concentrated electrolyte induce the formation of NaF-rich SEI on the Na surface. The double-layer structure with thermal stability achieves rapid sodium ion transfer and effectively inhibits the growth of sodium dendrites. As shown in Fig. 6(g), the cell using highly concentrated electrolyte + 1% SbF3 shows extended cycle life and effectively avoided dendrite penetration through the separator, which will cause battery short circuit with instantaneous intense release of heat, and ultimately thermal runaway [93]. 3.1.1.5 Others As one of the inherent safety issues of electrolytes, high corrosiveness does not receive widespread attention like flammability, but it also brings significant safety hazards. Organic electrolyte modification provides an effective approach to reduce the corrosiveness of the electrolyte to aluminum foil, and reduce the risk of short circuit and thermal runaway of SIBs. To illustrate, a stable passive layer can be formed on the surface of aluminum foil by adjusting the solvent composition, which can reduce the corrosion of aluminum caused by direct contact with the electrolyte [94,95]. In addition, the protection of aluminum can also be achieved by eliminating free solvent molecules through developing highly concentrated electrolyte [81,96]. In recent years, many researches have noticed that organic electrolyte modification can also improve the safety of cathodes. By constructing a stable CEI, inhibiting transition metal dissolution, and reconstructing cathode surface, organic electrolyte modification can effectively enhance the thermal and structural stability of the cathode. However, the cathode improvement mechanism based on organic electrolyte modification still needs further in-depth research [97,98]. By adjusting the components, organic electrolytes modification can improve the electrolyte intrinsic stability and have a positive impact on the safety issues of the anode and cathode, such as sodium dendrites, SEI dissolution, side reactions, thermal decomposition, and mechanical structure damage. Although these methods improve the battery safety to some extent, the side effects, such as reducing the electrochemical performance or increasing costs of the battery, are required consideration. How to balance safety with performance and cost will be the main goal of future research on organic electrolytes. 3.1.2 Solid-state electrolytes SSEs is generally divided into three categories: inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs), solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), and composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs). Compared with traditional organic electrolytes, SSEs exhibit excellent thermal stability, low flammability, and low electrochemical reactivity, and are considered a future solution for developing high-energy density and high-safety SIBs [20,21,99–101]. 3.1.2.1 Low flammability Organic liquid electrolytes are widely used in SIBs due to their excellent electrochemical performance, but their flammability has become the most serious safety hazard for SIBs. The excellent thermal stability and extremely low flammability of SSEs make it the best alternative to organic liquid electrolytes. Over the years, the practical demand for developing low flammability electrolytes has driven the development of SSEs. In the 1960s, β-alumina materials have been found to have excellent refractory property, excellent ionic conductivity, and high electronic resistivity [102]. β-alumina is considered a possible alternative to organic liquid electrolytes, and this study also marks the beginning of solid-state electrochemical research. Subsequently, Goodenough et al. developed the first NASICON type material with high ionic conductivity, Na1+ x Zr2P3− x Si x O12 (0 ≤ x ≤ 3), which can provide an open three-dimensional channel for rapid Na ion transport [103]. The composition of NASICON is very flexible, and the crystal structure of rhombic NASICON and possible elemental compositions of NASICONs are shown in Fig. 7 (a) [104]. In addition, NASICON has a low coefficient of thermal expansion, high thermal, and chemical stability, making solid-state SIBs practically feasible [105]. Since then, the development of solid-state SIBs has embarked on a fast track, with new SSEs systems continuously being successfully developed, such as sulfides and complex hydrides [106]. ISEs generally has good thermal stability and low flammability, and full batteries assembled using NASICON electrolyte (Na3Zr2Si2PO12) and cathode (Na3V2(PO4)3) can even operate stably at high temperatures of 200 °C [107]. By doping NASICON with metal elements, ionic conductivity and thermal stability can be further improved [108]. SPEs also possess superior thermal stability and lower flammability than liquid organic electrolytes. For example, when Na[(FSO2)(n-C4F9SO2)N] is blended with poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO), its decomposition temperature can reach 300 °C (Fig. 7b), making its application as an SPE sufficiently stable in solid-state SIBs [109]. However, as the temperature continues to rise, SPEs will decompose to form low-boiling by-products, which can react violently with the anode and release a large amount of heat. In addition, SPEs also possess a certain degree of flammability derived from its inherent organic characteristics, so solid-state SIBs based on SPEs still face the risk of combustion and explosion [110]. By adding fluorine-based and phosphorus-based flame-retardant additives to the SPEs matrix, the thermal safety of SPEs can be effectively enhanced. In addition, filling ceramic fillers (NASICON) into SPEs can effectively improve thermal stability and reduce flammability. For example, CPE composed of NaTFSI, PEO and NASICON exhibits high-temperature stability far exceeding that of PEO (Fig. 7c) [111]. The NZP-PEO@IL obtained by coupling PEO and NASICON through ionic liquid has extremely low flammability and can maintain its overall structure after continuous ignition for 6 s [112]. 3.1.2.2 Low electrochemical reactivity Traditional organic liquid electrolytes have high electrochemical reactivity, which not only poses significant safety issues but also limits the application of high-voltage cathode materials. Due to excellent electrochemical stability, SSEs are considered the key to developing high-voltage and high-energy-density SIBs [113–115]. ISEs have extremely high oxidation potentials, such as NASICON-based Na3Zr2Si2PO12, which can maintain electrochemical stability at 5 V and meet the requirements of most high-voltage SIBs [116]. Additionally, Na5YSi4O12 with a super stable structure can even maintain stability at ultra-high voltages of 8.0 V. As shown in Fig. 7(d), except for a pair of oxidation-reduction peaks attributed to sodium plating and stripping occurred near 0 V, no additional current peaks related to electrolyte decomposition can be observed, indicating that Na5YSi4O12 has extremely low electrochemical reactivity [117]. Many SPEs with relatively poor electrochemical stability are prone to reduction and oxidative decomposition, which will aggravate the decomposition of SEI, and generate additional heat, increasing the safety risks of solid-state SIBs. However, they can still effectively enhance electrochemical stability by combining with ISEs. For example, the Na3.4Zr1.8Mg0.2Si2PO12-PEO12-NaFSI (NZSPO) composite electrolyte can maintain superior electrochemical stability below 4.5 V (Fig. 7e) [118]. 3.1.2.3 Suppress sodium dendrite For batteries using organic liquid electrolytes, dendrites piercing the separator and causing short circuits are serious safety issues. The inherent physical strength of SSEs makes them less susceptible to penetration by sodium dendrites, and thus the strategy of suppressing dendrites by SSEs is extremely feasible in SIBs [16,52]. NASICON-based SSEs has high strength and good dendrite tolerance, which can effectively suppress dendrites [119]. For example, the compact NASICON-based Na5YSi4O12 can effectively extend the life of Na metal batteries by suppressing dendrites. As shown in Fig. 7(f), Na||Na5YSi4O12||Na battery can stably cycle for 1000 h at a current density of 0.3 mA cm−2. The interface between Na metal and Na5YSi4O12 after 200 h of cycling (Fig. 7g) is more tightly than before cycling, which can effectively suppress the generation of dendrites [117]. However, due to the poor wettability compared to liquid electrolytes, SSEs often leads to poor solid interface contact, which seriously affects its ability to suppress dendrites. Severe poor solid interface contact will increase the local current density on the surface of anode, making the Na plating layer uneven and leading to the growth of Na dendrites. In addition, there are micro-defects such as micropores and grain boundaries on the surface of the SSEs. The deposition of Na on the defects will cause considerable internal stress, causing cracks and providing channels for Na dendrites to invade the interior of the SSEs. As the crack expands, it eventually causes a short circuit and instantaneous intense release of heat, resulting in the battery to burn and explode [99,110]. By introducing interlayer such as polymer, SnF2, and AlF3 layers between SSEs and Na anode, interface contact can be improved [116,120,121]. The behavior of sodium plating/stripping for Na3.2Ca0.1Zr1.9Si2PO12 (NCZSP) with or without SnF2 coating is shown in Fig. 7(h). SnF2 can form a uniform and dense composite protective layer at the interface, with excellent alkaline and mechanical properties. This layer can achieve efficient interface contact and suppress the nucleation and growth of dendrites, avoiding thermal runaway caused by short circuits. Due to the effective suppression of Na dendrites, the Na||NCZSP-SnF2||Na battery has a long cycle life of 1300 h at 0.2 mA cm−2 without short-circuits (Fig. 7i) [121]. 3.1.2.4 Others In addition to low flammability, high electrochemical stability, and high mechanical strength, SSEs also have extremely high chemical stability. Compared to traditional organic liquid electrolytes, SSEs are less likely to react with the anode and cathode. On the anode side, SSEs can form unique SEI, effectively suppressing the occurrence of side reactions. On the cathode side, SSEs can eliminate the chemical erosion of the cathode by the decomposition products of the liquid electrolyte and the dissolution of transition metal cations in the liquid electrolyte, effectively improving the thermodynamic and mechanical stability of the cathode [113,114,122]. However, it is difficult for SSEs to completely avoid interfacial reactions with highly reactive Na metal. Especially at high temperatures, the melting of Na metal with low melting point will destroy the SEI, aggravating the exothermic interface reaction between Na and SSEs [30]. As the temperature continues to rise, the SSEs reacts violently with the cathode and releases a large amount of heat, leading to thermal runaway of solid-state SIBs [123]. In order to reduce the harm caused by interfacial reactions, it is still necessary to further develop SSEs systems with higher chemical stability, such as sulfide-based SSEs. In addition, the interface stability can be further improved through cathode or anode modification, such as anode framework structure design and cathode surface coating [21,30,99]. SSEs with low flammability and high voltage stability, making high-safety, high-voltage, and high-energy density SIBs possible, are considered a promising substitute for traditional organic liquid electrolytes. In addition, the high mechanical strength of SSEs can effectively suppress sodium dendrites, and the high chemical stability enables SSEs to effectively alleviate SEI dissolution and side reactions on the anode surface, as well as thermal decomposition and mechanical structural damage of the cathode. However, solid-state SIBs based on SSEs still need to continue to enhance safety, improve electrochemical performance and reduce cost to meet the needs of commercialization. In the development of high-security SSEs, a large number of new advanced technologies are deeply applied, which will increase research and development efficiency and bring more effective security solutions. For example, the use of high-throughput computational techniques for early screening can lead to more targeted and efficient development of new SSEs systems [104]. In addition, artificial intelligence technology can be used to establish reliable safety detection and early warning systems to provide timely warnings and responses to safety issues, such as overheating, overcharging and short circuits, thereby preventing battery safety accidents in early stages [124]. 3.1.3 Aqueous electrolytes Recently, replacing flammable organic liquid electrolytes to achieve high-safety SIBs has received increasing attention. Aqueous electrolytes directly use water as a solvent, which has the advantages of inherent non flammability, low cost, and environmental friendliness. Aqueous electrolytes are a possible alternative to organic liquid electrolytes in addition to SSEs [22,125]. There are various mature SIBs systems employing aqueous electrolytes that have been successfully developed. For example, Na3MnTi(PO4)3-Na3MnTi(PO4)3 symmetric battery. The Na3MnTi(PO4)3 with NASICON structure (Fig. 8 a) serves as both the anode and cathode, achieving sodium ion insertion and extraction through reversible redox of Ti4+/Ti3+ and Mn3+/Mn2+. The cycling performance of Na3MnTi(PO4)3-Na3MnTi(PO4)3 symmetric battery in 1.0 M Na2SO4 aqueous electrolyte is shown in Fig. 8(b). After 100 charge and discharge cycles, approximately 98% of the initial capacity can still be retained with coulombic efficiency exceeds 99%, showing great application value [126]. Although aqueous SIBs have greatly improved safety, the selection of cathodes and anodes in aqueous SIBs is limited by the narrow electrochemical stability window (1.23 V). The water-in-salt strategy can effectively broaden the electrochemical stability window of water, achieving aqueous SIBs with high energy density and excellent cycling stability [127]. When salt concentration reached ultra-high level, the solvation sheath structure will undergo significant changes. The activity of water in the electrolyte can be greatly reduced, and the amount of free water can be effectively reduced, thereby inhibiting the decomposition of water [128]. For example, a high concentration NaOTF-TEAOTF (9 mol kg−1 NaOTF + 22 mol kg−1 tetraethylammonium triflate) aqueous electrolyte can significantly expand the electrochemical stability window to 3.3 V (Fig. 8c). The charge and discharge profiles of NaMnHCF||NaOTF-TEAOTF||NaTiOPO4 battery are shown in Fig. 8(d); the full cell can reversibly charge and discharge in the voltage range of 0.7–2.6 V, far exceeding the tolerance range of traditional aqueous SIBs [129]. The dissolution of transition metals in water also limits the application of aqueous SIBs. During the charging process of aqueous SIBs, stable Mn2+ in Na1.58Fe0.07Mn0.97Fe(CN)6·2.56H2O (NaFeMnF) gradually changes to unstable Mn3+, inducing Mn dissolution and severe structural damage of cathode. However, by introducing low concentrations of Na4Fe(CN)6 as additive into a 17.6 M NaClO4 electrolyte, this problem can be effectively alleviated. The Na4Fe(CN)6 attached to the surface of NaFeMnF can in situ capture dislocation Mn and maintain structural stability (Fig. 8e). The EPR spectra of the fully discharged cathode in different electrolytes after 300 cycles are shown in Fig. 8(f). The g-factor is positively correlated with the relative content of Mn2+ in the electrode. Compared with the cathode in a unmodified electrolyte, the cathode in electrolyte with Na4Fe(CN)6 additive exhibits a higher g-factor, further proving that the cation capture strategy can effectively inhibit the dissolution of Mn, prevent the decomposition of Mn-based cathode, and improve the overall safety of aqueous SIBs [130]. The safety of aqueous electrolytes benefits from the inherent non-flammability of water, but is also limited by the narrow electrochemical stability window and the high solubility of transition metals in water. Therefore, aqueous electrolytes with extremely high-safety are difficult to widely apply due to their low output voltage and energy density. At present, methods such as water-in-salt can effectively expand the electrochemical stability window of aqueous electrolytes and improve cycle stability of aqueous SIBs, but the use of high concentration salts will reduce the original cost advantage of aqueous SIBs. How to achieve high energy density aqueous SIBs with low cost will be the most severe challenge in this field. 3.2 Anode Addressing the safety issues associated with anode, including sodium dendrites, SEI decomposition, and side reactions, is crucial for the design of high-safe SIBs. Up to now, numerous strategies from anode, such as artificial SEI and anode bulk modification, have been developed to suppress anode safety issues and improve the overall safety of SIBs [23,40]. 3.2.1 Artificial SEI Artificial SEI layer refers to an artificial protective layer constructed on the pristine anode surface through chemical and physical methods. On the one hand, artificial SEI has extremely high mechanical strength and ionic conductivity, which can regulate sodium ion flux, and inhibit the formation and growth of dendrites. On the other hand, artificial SEI can also improve the stability of SEI by affecting the composition of natural SEI, inhibit SEI decomposition and side reaction [23]. 3.2.1.1 Suppress sodium dendrite During sodium deposition/stripping, uneven sodium ion flux can lead to the growth of sodium dendrites on the anode surface. The disorderly growth of sodium dendrites can puncture the separator and cause cell short circuits, affecting the electrochemical performance of SIBs. Uniform and stable artificial SEI can prevent direct contact between the anode and electrolyte to suppress side reactions, and homogenize sodium ion flux to inhibit nucleation and growth of sodium dendrites [23]. The artificial SEI on the anode surface can be built through chemical methods such as atomic layer deposition (ALD), molecular layer deposition (MLD), and electro polymerization [131,132]. A stable Al2O3 protective layer can be introduced on the surface of sodium metal anode through ALD technology (Fig. 9 a). Al2O3 has extremely high mechanical strength to withstand volume changes during the sodium deposition/stripping process. Even after multiple deposition/stripping cycles, the surface of Al2O3-coated sodium metal remains smooth without obvious sodium dendrite growth (Fig. 9b) [133]. The MLD technologies are used to generate an inorganic-organic MLD-alucone protecting layer on the surface of sodium metal anodes. The MLD-alucone layer has chemical stability towards liquid electrolytes and can form a stable SEI layer on the sodium metal anode, thereby homogenizing sodium flux [132]. In addition, nanohybrid films with nanoalloy interface can be prepared on sodium metal surfaces by precisely controlling the ALD/MLD process (Fig. 9c). The nanoalloy interface is very robust and has chemical/electrochemical stability, which can effectively suppress sodium dendrites. Based on the nanohybrid film protection, the symmetrical battery shows an ultra-long cycle life of 2000 h at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 without short circuits by dendrites (Fig. 9d) [134]. Fabricating a protective layer on the sodium anode through physical methods can also effectively suppress sodium dendrites [23,135]. For example, a free-standing composite protective layer (FCPL) can be prepared in an air environment, and then laminated onto a Na metal electrode by roll-pressing. FCPL exhibits high ionic conductivity and excellent mechanical properties, which can provide uniform sodium flux, effectively suppress dendrite growth, and improve the safety of SIBs. In addition, the process of physical methods is relatively simple, and there will be no uneven thickness caused by chemical reactions that are difficult to control [136]. 3.2.1.2 Inhibiting SEI decomposition and side reactions SEI originates from the complex electrochemical and chemical reactions between the anode and electrolyte. These SEIs are unstable and easily decompose at high temperatures, leading to sustained side reactions between the anode and electrolyte. By adjusting the distribution and proportion of organic and inorganic components in the SEI layer, artificial SEI can enhance the stability of SEI, suppress the occurrence of side reactions, and improve the safety of SIBs. Artificial SEI can rationalize the distribution of organic and inorganic components in the SEI layer, enhancing the stability of SEI. For example, a stable Al2O3 protective layer can be generated on the HC surface through ALD technology (Fig. 9e). Al2O3 can regulate the distribution of organic and inorganic components in the SEI layer, filling the gaps between the inorganic components with organic components. This SEI film with a reasonable distribution of organic and inorganic components not only has extremely high stability, but also prevents electrolyte penetration and reduces side reactions [137]. Artificial SEI can also increase the proportion of inorganic components in SEI, enhancing its thermal and mechanical stability. A stable AlF3 protective layer can be coated on the surface of the HC anode through chemical coprecipitation. The AlF3 protective layer will have a significant impact on the formation process of SEI. The XPS analysis of SEI on surface of HC and HC@AlF3 (hard carbon coated with AlF3) are shown in Fig. 9(f). As the discharge process continues, the organic components in the SEI on the surface of HC gradually increase, while the inorganic components in the SEI on the surface of HC@AlF3 become more abundant. This inorganic-rich SEI has excellent thermal stability, mechanical stability, and superior ion shuttle performance, which can effectively suppress the continuous decomposition of the electrolyte and improve battery safety [138]. Artificial SEI can effectively alleviate safety issues caused by sodium dendrites, SEI decomposition, and side reactions, improving the overall safety of SIBs. Currently, various chemical and physical methods have been used to manufacture artificial SEI. However, these methods are generally complex in process and have poor applicability. Developing an artificial SEI synthesis method that is simple in process and suitable for various SIBs systems remains a daunting challenge. 3.2.2 Anode bulk modification To overcome the issues on the anode side, many adjusting methods are concentrated on electrolyte modification, while the anode bulk modification is often neglected. Anode bulk modification includes framework structure design and surface modification, which can effectively suppress sodium dendrites and SEI decomposition and side reactions by adjusting the structure and chemical environment of the anode surface [24,139]. 3.2.2.1 Suppress sodium dendrite Sodium metal batteries are plagued by dendrite problems. Especially at high current densities, sodium deposition on the anode surface will be highly concentrated, forming a rough and uneven surface to generate sodium dendrites and affect the safety of SIBs. By reducing the local current density, guiding the uniform nucleation, anode bulk modification strategies can effectively suppress dendrites [23,25,140]. The design of the anode framework structure can provide a larger conductive surface to reduce the actual local current density, and effectively suppress sodium dendrites. For example, carbonized wood with porous channels as carbon framework structure provides high conductivity surface area, which can reduce the effective local current density and lead to uniform sodium nucleation (Fig. 10 a). In addition, the unique porous channel structure of carbonized wood can limit the sodium plating/stripping process and prevent uncontrolled sodium deposition. The symmetric battery using Na-wood electrode has a long cyclic life of 500 h without being short circuited by dendrites (Fig. 10b) [141]. Anode surface modification through doping and other methods can also effectively suppress sodium dendrites. For example, an oxygen-doped carbon foam (OCF) anode can be synthesized from water-soluble starch (Fig. 10c). The anode has both a porous structure and a basophilic surface brought about by doped oxygen. The rich pore structure brings a larger specific surface area, effectively reducing the actual local current density on the surface of OCF. The basophilic nucleation layer formed by introducing oxygen atoms effectively reduces the nucleation barrier on the anode surface, promoting the uniform distribution of Na ion flux and facilitating sodium metal to deposit uniformly on the surface of the OCF electrode. The basophilic surface of OCF can not only affect the nucleation process, but also effectively guide the subsequent growth process, thereby inhibiting the growth of dendrites. As shown in Fig. 10(d), symmetrical cell using Na@OCF electrodes exhibits an ultra-long life of 3000 h at a current density of 2.0 mA cm−2 [142]. Surface modification is also applicable to other carbon anode electrodes. The oxygen-functionalized 3D carbon nanotube network (Of-CNT) has dense and uniformly distributed basophilic functional groups (Fig. 10e), which can guide the uniform nucleation and ordered growth of sodium, effectively suppressing sodium dendrites [53]. 3.2.2.2 Inhibiting SEI decomposition and side reactions SEI is generated by the decomposition of electrolyte under the catalytic effect of the anode surface. The surface structure and properties of the anode are important aspects that determine the structure and composition of SEI. Anode bulk modification, especially surface modification, can effectively improve the stability of the SEI [139]. The introduction of surface functional groups and other surface modification methods can effectively enhance the stability of SEI. Surface functional groups can adjust the structure and surface properties of the anode or directly participate in the formation process of SEI to improve the stability of SEI [139]. For example, oxygen functional groups can be incorporated into hard carbon through the oxygen plasma method, during which unstable hard carbon groups are converted into oxygen groups such as carbonyl and hydroxyl groups. On the one hand, compared with the original hard carbon groups, these interfacial oxygen groups have higher chemical stability towards the electrolyte and can effectively inhibit the decomposition of the electrolyte. On the other hand, there is a strong interaction between carbonyl or hydroxyl groups and the SEI, which can provide strong adhesion for SEI and greatly improve its stability [143]. The ex-situ XPS analysis of SEI on the surface of OCF electrodes with oxygen groups is shown in Fig. 10(f). The chemical composition of the SEI remains unchanged even after 1000 cycles, proving that oxygen groups can effectively inhibit the decomposition of SEI and prevent the occurrence of side reactions [142]. Overall, anode bulk modification can improve the safety of SIBs through framework structure design and surface modification. Anode bulk modification can effectively suppress sodium dendrites by reducing the actual local current density on the anode surface and guiding the uniform nucleation of sodium. In addition, anode bulk modification can regulate the surface chemical environment and properties to inhibit SEI decomposition and side reactions. Anode bulk modification can effectively improve safety while enhancing electrochemical performance of SIBs, which will be an important research direction in enhancing the safety of SIBs. 3.3 Cathode Under critical conditions such as temperature and internal stress, the internal crystal structure of cathode will suffer from instability, leading to serious safety issues including cathode thermal decomposition and structural damage. Unlike the safety issues of the anode, which often occur on the contact surface with the electrolyte, the thermal decomposition and structural damage of the cathode materials will be quickly expanded from local to the interior areas of the cathode, causing the overall collapse of the cathode. This means that addressing cathode safety issues requires improving the overall stability of the cathode [28]. Cathode bulk design refers to a type of cathode modification strategies that enhances the stability of cathode materials by affecting the crystal structure and phase transition process. Unlike anode bulk modification, which focuses on regulating the chemical environment and properties of the anode surface, cathode bulk modification requires attention to improving the overall stability of the cathode material. By using metal cation substitution and vacancy generation and other means, cathode bulk design can effectively suppress the thermal decomposition and mechanical structural damage of the cathode, improving the safety of SIBs [59]. 3.3.1 Inhibiting cathode thermal decomposition When the battery temperature reaches the critical temperature, the cathode will undergo thermal decomposition from surface to interior, releasing a large amount of heat with oxygen. The rapid increase of temperature and internal pressure of the battery caused by thermal decomposition will greatly increase the risk of combustion and explosion. Cathode bulk design can stabilize the crystal structure and regulate phase transition process, thus improve the thermal decomposition temperature to postpone the starting of decomposition, enhancing the safety of SIBs [28]. As the most traditional SIBs cathode system, the thermal stability of layered oxides strongly depends on the composition of transition metals. Through substituting the unstable transition metal elements by Cr, Mn, Fe, and other thermally stable elements, the thermal stability of the cathode can be improved [144]. In layered oxides, Ni-based and Co-based layered oxides have extremely poor thermal stability and undergo thermal decomposition at low temperatures with the release of a large amount of oxygen [145]. Due to the excellent chemical stability of Cr4+, Cr-based layered oxides generally have higher thermal stability. Thus Na x CrO2 decomposes and releases oxygen only at high temperatures exceeding 500 °C, confirming its extremely high thermal safety as cathode material (Fig. 11 a) [146]. Mn element also contributes to improving the thermal stability of the cathode. The DSC curve of Na[Ni x Co y Mn z ]O2 (Na-NCM xyz ) cathodes are shown in Fig. 11(b). With the increase content of Mn, the thermal decomposition temperature of cathode gradually shifts towards high temperature, accompanied by a decrease in heat generation [147]. The high-entropy configuration strategy, as a unique modification strategy, can also effectively improve the thermal stability of the cathode in SIBs. The improvement of cathode thermal stability by high-entropy configuration cathode materials does not rely on the stability of single element, but on the enhancement of TM–O binding energy through multi-component distribution, thereby maintaining the integrity of cathode structure and improving thermal safety. For example, compared to NaNi0.4Fe0.2Mn0.4O2 (NFM424), NaNi0.25Mg0.05Cu0.1Fe0.2Mn0.2Ti0.1Sn0.1O2 (HEO424) with a high entropy configuration has a higher thermal decomposition temperature and lower heat generation (Fig. 11c) [148]. In addition, research has also shown that doping a small amount of cation can also enhance the thermal stability of the cathode and suppress thermal decomposition. For example, Ca2+ doping can increase the phase transition temperature of Na3.32Fe2.34(P2O7)2 (NFPP) from 450 to 500 °C, greatly improving the thermal stability of NFPP and reducing its safety risks during battery operation [61]. 3.3.2 Suppress structural damage The cathode of SIBs undergoes complex phase transitions and irreversible lattice changes during sodium insertion/extraction, leading to the accumulation of internal stress and ultimately causing mechanical structural damage. The cathode bulk design can reduce irreversible phase transitions and enhances stability of crystal structure through metal cation substitution and vacancy generation, thereby suppressing mechanical structural damage and enhancing the safety of SIBs [58]. One of the most effective strategies to suppress mechanical structural damage is to substitute different metals at the transition metal layer points, causing the cathode deviating from irreversible phase transitions and enhancing the stability of the crystal structure. For example, partially substituting Mn4+ with Ti4+ can expand the interlayer distance of TMO2, thus suppressing the irreversible harmful phase transitions in high voltage, which effectively improves the structural stability of the cathode [65]. For Mn-based cathode materials, in addition to irreversible phase transitions, severe lattice distortion caused by the Jahn-Teller effect can also disrupt the mechanical structural stability of the cathode. The electronic state and corresponding structural evolution of transition metals in the cathode can be studied through X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra (Fig. 11d). During charging, Mn K-edge transfers to higher energy state, and then transfers back to energy below the original state during the discharging process, which proves that Mn element can cause irreversible lattice distortion of the cathode. However, the Cu K-edge remained almost unchanged, indicating that the Cu element can act as a stabilizer for lattice distortion. Partial substitution of Mn cation with Cu cation can effectively suppress the Jahn-Teller effect and prevent mechanical structural damage, which can cause battery short circuits, even combustion and explosion [149]. Native vacancies can also enhance the reversibility of cathode phase transition and the stability of crystal structure. For example, the presence of natural vacancies endows Na4/7[Mn6/7(□Mn)1/7]O2 (NMO-vacancies) with high structural flexibility and lattice stability (Fig. 11e). The in-situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of NMO-vacancies (Fig. 11f) showed that the shift of diffraction peak can be almost ignored during charging, exhibiting typical zero-strain feature, which proves that the high structural stability of NMO-vacancies [150]. High-entropy materials, with multiple elements co-existing in single-phase, also exhibit extremely high structural stability. The HEO424 with high-entropy configuration has a larger TMO2 interlayer spacing and stronger TM–O and Na–O bonding energies compared to NFM424, which can enhance crystal structure stability by reducing Jahn-Teller distortion and lattice parameter changes (Fig. 11g). The lattice parameter evolutions of the cathode can be directly tracked through in-situ XRD measurements (Fig. 11 h). During the charging and discharging process, HEO424 exhibits smaller lattice parameter changes, which is associated with less irreversible phase transitions and weaker mechanical anisotropy, thereby reducing structural deformation and suppressing mechanical structural damage [148]. Cathode bulk design can effectively suppress cathode thermal decomposition and structural damage, improving the safety of SIBs. More importantly, cathode bulk design often effectively enhances the electrochemical performance of SIBs, especially the cycling stability, compared to other methods which improve the safety at the cost of electrochemical performance. In summary, numerous safety strategies, based on electrolyte, anode, and cathode, have been used to improve the safety of SIBs. The safety strategies based on electrolytes can suppress the electrolyte intrinsic stability, and relieve safety issues faced by anodes and cathodes. But safety strategies based on anode mainly relieve the safety issues such as sodium dendrites, SEI decomposition, and side reactions, as well as cathode safety strategies mainly focuses on cathode thermal decomposition and mechanical structural damage. Targeted selection should be made in the design of safety strategies to the different root of safety issues. 4 Conclusions and perspectives In this review, we firstly summary the safety issues of SIBs and reveal the root causes of these security issues. Then, starts from the root causes of safety issues, we propose numerous modifications methods that are based on the key components of SIBs and explain their underlying improvement mechanisms. In addition, we further systematically compare and analyze the various improvement strategies, including advantages and disadvantages, as well as future development directions. Based on the above discussion and analysis, to enhance the overall safety of SIBs in practical utilization, the design of battery components should consider the following points. (1) Different safety issues are generated from distinguished root causes. The intrinsic instability of the electrolytes including high flammability, high electrochemical reactivity, and corrosiveness, poses electrolytes significant safety issues. The safety issues of anode, such as sodium dendrite, SEI decomposition and side reactions, originate from the complex chemical and electrochemical reactions occurring between the anode and the electrolyte. The unstable crystal structure and irreversible phase transition of the cathode can cause serious thermal decomposition and structural damage. Only strategies that based on the root causes of safety problems associated with different SIBs components can effectively improve the security of SIBs. Notably, mechanistic studies on safety issues of SIBs, especially those related to the cathode, are not in-depth enough. For example, the underlying mechanisms by which CEI affects cathode thermal stability and mechanical structural stability need to be further elucidated. (2) There are linkage reactions between security issues. For example, organic electrolyte with high electrochemical reactivity will decompose under high voltage to produce harmful by-products such as HF, enhancing the inherent corrosiveness of the electrolyte and severely accelerating the decomposition of SEI and cathode. The decomposition of SEI and cathode will release a large amount of heat with the liberation of oxygen, creating conditions for the combustion of battery. This means that building high-safety SIBs requires simultaneously considering multiple safety issues that exist in the electrolyte, anode, and cathode. (3) Targeted selection should be made in the design of high-safety materials according to the characteristics of the material and real application requirements (Fig. 12 ). For example, through flexible component adjustment, organic liquid electrolytes modification can solve multiple safety issues simultaneously.
