The application of SSEs can greatly improve the safety of SIBs to meet the most stringent security standards. Anode bulk modification and cathode bulk design, with enhancing effect on electrochemical performance, can effectively balance the pursuit of safety and high electrochemical performance in SIBs. (4) For achieving high-safety SIBs, some future development directions are suggested. By adjusting the components, electrolyte modification with unique flexibility can not only alleviate multiple safety issues to block malignant chain reaction, but also enhance the inhibitory effect on specific safety issues to meet actual application requirements. Building upon this foundation, modification of SEEs with inherent stability can more significantly enhance battery safety and exhibit exceptional development potential. Therefore, constructing high-safety solid-state SIBs based on modified SSEs is the key to solve safety issues of SIBs, and more attention can be paid to the following important directions to develop safer solid-state SIBs. (a) Explore novel SSEs high-safety materials with the help of new advanced technologies. For example, using high-throughput computational techniques for targeted early screening can greatly improve the research and development efficiency of solid-state SIBs. (b) Improve the interface compatibility between SSEs and electrodes from a composite perspective. Combining multi-level modification approaches to improve interface contact and suppress interface reactions for avoiding thermal runaway, including SSEs, anode bulk, cathode bulk design and modification, and introduction of artificial interface layers. (c) Establish a reliable security detection and early warning system. Utilize artificial intelligence technology to establish a reliable safety detection system, providing timely warning and response to safety problems such as overheating, overcharging and short circuit, which can prevent the entire battery system from losing control. In addition, we propose that comprehensive modification methods to improve the safety with enhancement of electrochemical performance need to be further explored, such as anode bulk modification and cathode bulk design. Yingshuai Wang is currently a Ph.D. candidate supervised by Prof. Hongcai Gao at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology. He received his bachelor's degree from North China Electric Power University (NCEPU) in 2020. His research interests focus on the design of high-performance electrode materials for electrochemical energy storage systems including sodium-ion batteries and zinc-ion batteries. Feng Wu is the director of the Professor Commission of the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, the director of the Green Energy Research Institute, and the Vice President of the China Battery Industry Association. As the chief scientist, he has hosted the National Key Program for Basic Research of China (973 projects), and the Basic Research on New Rechargeable Batteries and Related Materials. His major research interest is functional materials for energy storage devices. In 2012, he was awarded the IBA Research Award for outstanding research on battery material and systems for electric vehicles. Yumin Qian is currently a researcher at the School of Physics, Beijing Institute of Technology. He received his Ph.D. degree from Institute of Physics Chinese Acadamy of Science, and then worked as researcher at National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology(AIST) and The University of Texas at Austin. His current research focuses on DFT investigation for new materials and their reaction mechanisms for electrochemical energy storage and conversion systems, including Li/Na-ion batteries, solid-state batteries, and catalysis. Hongcai Gao is currently a professor at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology. He received his Ph.D. degree from Nanyang Technological University, and then worked as a postdoctoral researcher in The University of Texas at Austin. His current research focuses on developing new materials and investigating their reaction mechanisms for electrochemical energy storage systems, including lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries, and solid-state batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with advantages of abundant resource and low cost have emerged as promising candidates for the next-generation energy storage systems. However, safety issues existing in electrolytes, anodes, and cathodes bring about frequent accidents regarding battery fires and explosions and impede the development of high-performance SIBs. Therefore, safety analysis and high-safety battery design have become prerequisites for the development of advanced energy storage systems. The reported reviews that only focus on a specific issue are difficult to provide overall guidance for building high-safety SIBs. To overcome the limitation, this review summarizes the recent research progress from the perspective of key components of SIBs for the first time and evaluates the characteristics of various improvement strategies. By orderly analyzing the root causes of safety problems associated with different components in SIBs (including electrolytes, anodes, and cathodes), corresponding improvement strategies for each component were discussed systematically. In addition, some noteworthy points and perspectives including the chain reaction between security issues and the selection of improvement strategies tailored to different needs have also been proposed. In brief, this review is designed to deepen our understanding of the SIBs safety issues and provide guidance and assistance for designing high-safety SIBs.
